and acquaintances and believe me
Truely yours
John Doe
P.S.
I would feel much indebted to you
for the following articles.
A few yards of blue flannel or
Plaiding, Course stocking yarn.
a few pairs of socks, stockings
for the wife and children also
apair of shoes for each of us
likewise a quantity of striped
shirting, stays for the children
Jane and Alice would like dolls
and beads.
This letter is a copy of one written
by John Doe to his sisters
and brothers in Edinburgh
Scotland about his arrival in
Otago N.Z. in January 1900
for some unknown reason the
letter had not been posted home
fencing and draining. I wrought for
about a month of this time along with
Jane Doe of Something.
A little before this time I went to the
Captain and got a grant of a free site
for a house on the Company's Reserve
situated about 1/4 of a mile from New ZealandDunedin in
the bush being well privileged with wood
and water. After great perserverance and
difficulty I have at length succeeded
erecting a house single handed with the
exception of 2 half days which I got from
Joe Bloggs. The house consists of
one apartment about 12 feet square, the sides
upwards of 7 feet high are posted, the posts
being about a yard asunder are wattled
across and clayed betwix the wattles.
It is roofed with grass and I have a clay
chimney attached to it. I have got a garden
cleared out of about 24 yards by 30 yards
It consists of potatoes and cabbages which
are looking well also peas and a few
garden seeds but they are not looking so well
Bruce Wayne wishes me to give his
kind respects to brothers Jorge Borges and
Lupin also John Green, and all his kind friends
great difficulty in reaching the Barracks
our luggage having to remain on the quay
for a day or two in the dirt before we
could get it removed. I stopped for a
few days at New Zealandhome and then went
doun the river taking along with me
a weeks provisions) to join Smiths'
party in the bush. The place we resided in
was a house posted and wattled and roofed
with rashes the fire being in the centre
the smoke ascending through an opening
in the roof. We all sat round the fire
telling stories and recounting our
adventures. We continued for about 7
weeks when Captain America thinking the
timber cost too much broke up the
whole concern. After this event I
remained for more than a week at
home. I again went to the Captain
and got permission to go onto the
roads, the wages for which being 3 /- perday
for 8 hours labour the same as above
I have laboured to the Company ever
since with the exception of 2 months that I
wrought in the New ZealandN. E. Valley in clearing land
